title: Sydney media advisor, 29, who's hoping to buy a house, offers a glimpse into get financial diary
text:
A 29-year-old media advisor who's on a $108,000 salary has revealed how she's hoping to get on the property ladder after saving $455,000.

The full-time worker said she shares a joint savings account with her fiancé where they both deposit anywhere between $5,000 to $6,000 a month.

The couple recently moved in with her parents so they could save in the hope of buying a property in Sydney, followed by a home in Europe.

Speaking to Mamamia, the young woman has offered a glimpse into her weekly financial diary - and how she putting away $2,000 in savings a fortnight.

A 29-year-old media advisor who's on a $108,000 salary has revealed how she's hoping to get on the property ladder after saving $455,000 (stock image)

The woman - who gets paid fortnightly - said she gets $6,530 monthly after tax.

As soon as she gets paid, she transfers $2,000 into joint savings account, while her fiancé deposits $3,000.

Her monthly expenses includes $65 on phone bill, $250 on public transport, $48 on gym membership, and $400 on groceries such as food, coffee and her dog's meals.

She sets aside $500 for splurging, which usually includes clothing, makeup and leisure activities but she has spent it mostly on her dog's training this month.

She said her 'regular monthly expenses' comes to a total of $700 'give or take'.

The woman and her fiancé have $455,000 in savings, $2,000 in investments and $20,000 in furniture and art.

The couple have never owned a car and she added she has no debt, loan, credit card, mortgage or HECS.

For work, she usually spends $5.15 on catching a train to work and another $5.15 on her way home, and about $10 on lunch if she doesn't pack any leftovers.

The 29-year-old said one of her biggest expenses is paying for her dog's training (stock image)

Every morning she makes an espresso and Greek yoghurt with kiwi fruit and psyllium husk at home - but ocassionally treats herself to a $3.50 coffee to go at a cafe.

During her lunch break on a Monday, she treated herself to two pairs of work shoes for $140. After work, she meets with a colleague at a bar where she spends just $10.

She managed to save on her dinner at an inner-city restaurant with her fiancé by using a $200 gift card.

Over the weekend, she ordered pancakes for $12 at a cafe, after visiting a few open houses at auction, including properties ranging between $1.2 to $1.5 million.

Her weekly expenses came to a total of $988.57.

'I spent a lot more than I expected to, largely because all my monthly bills were due on one day. I still managed to save double the amount that I spent, but looking at my bank account over the next week I will need to budget hard,' she said.

'I can't spend nearly $1,000 a week, that's ridiculous. There are a few things I could have avoided, such as having coffee out, and having lunch at work.

'However I only ate out a handful of times and that included going to dinner and paying with the gift voucher. Once I have a mega mortgage, I will have to rein it all in.'
description: An Australian media advisor, 29, who's on a $108,000 salary has revealed how she's hoping to get on the property ladder after saving $455,000.
authors: Cindy Tran For Daily Mail Australia
